body:
Since we're changing pretty much everything in [project 2022](/blog/project-2022) anyway, we might as well try to reduce our bundle size by removing our dependency on [Material UI](https://material-ui.com/), the React component framework that implements Google's material design.

MaterialUI is a large project, and it makes up a significant portion of the so-called *bundle size*, the amount of Javascript code we ship to the browser.

Obviously, for that size, MaterialUI brings a lot to the table, and it remains to be seen whether we can build everything without it.

Still, I want to try, and I've got a secret little helper in the form of [DaisyUI](https://daisyui.com/).

Before you think that we're swapping out one component library for another, DaisyUI works with TailwindCSS and the components it provides are CSS only. So no extra Javascript to ship ðŸŽ‰

## Can I haz themes?

Another thing that DaisyUI brings to the table is support for themeing. While TailwindCSS recently added support for dark mode, theming in DaisyUI is more flexible, allowing us to not only have dark and light versions of the site, but also a bunch of other themes.

For someone who gets bored easily like myself, that sounds great  ðŸ˜ƒ
caption: A daisy - Picture by Bess Hamiti via Pexels
title: Once more without MaterialUI: DaisyUI for CSS components and themes
author: joostdecock
intro: Since we're changing pretty much everything in project 2022 anyway, we might as well try to reduce our bundle size by removing our dependency on Material UI , the React component framework that implements Google's material design.
